channel.title: OverTheWire - Bandit on Gajendra Mahato
channel.description: Recent content in OverTheWire - Bandit on Gajendra Mahato

item.title: Bandit: Level 0 => Level 1
item.description: The goal of this level is to log into the game using SSH.&#x20;

item.title: Bandit: Level 1 => Level 2
item.description: The password for the next level is stored in a file called `-` located in the home directory.

item.title: Bandit: Level 2 => Level 3
item.description: The password for the next level is stored in a file called `spaces in this filename` located in the home directory.

item.title: Bandit: Level 3 => Level 4
item.description: The password for the next level is stored in a hidden file in the `inhere` directory.

item.title: Bandit: Level 4 => Level 5
item.description: The password for the next level is stored in the only human-readable file in the `inhere` directory. Tip: if your terminal is messed up, try the ‚Äúreset‚Äù command.

item.title: Bandit: Level 5 => Level 6
item.description: The password for the next level is stored in a file somewhere under the inhere directory and has all of the following properties:

item.title: Bandit: Level 6 => Level 7
item.description: The password for the next level is stored somewhere on the server and has all of the following properties:

item.title: Bandit: Level 7 => Level 8
item.description: The password for the next level is stored in the file `data.txt` next to the word `millionth`

item.title: Bandit: Level 8 => Level 9
item.description: The password for the next level is stored in the file `data.txt` and is the only line of text that occurs only once.

item.title: Bandit: Level 9 => Level 10
item.description: The password for the next level is stored in the file `data.txt` in one of the few human-readable strings, preceded by several `=` characters.

item.title: Bandit: Level 10 => Level 11
item.description: The password for the next level is stored in the file `data.txt`, which contains `base64` encoded data.

item.title: Bandit: Level 11 => Level 12
item.description: The password for the next level is stored in the file `data.txt`, where all lowercase (a-z) and uppercase (A-Z) letters have been rotated by 13 positions.

item.title: Bandit: Level 12 => Level 13
item.description: The password for the next level is stored in the file data.txt, which is a hexdump of a file that has been repeatedly compressed. For this level it may be useful to create a directory under /tmp in which you can work. Use mkdir with a hard to guess directory name. Or better, use the command ‚Äúmktemp -d‚Äù. Then copy the datafile using cp, and rename it using mv (read the manpages!)

item.title: Bandit: Level 13 => Level 14
item.description: The password for the next level is stored in `/etc/bandit_pass/bandit14` and can only be read by user `bandit14`. For this level, you don‚Äôt get the next password, but you get a private SSH key that can be used to log into the next level. **Note:** `localhost` is a hostname that refers to the machine you are working on.

item.title: Bandit: Level 14 => Level 15
item.description: The password for the next level can be retrieved by submitting the password of the current level to port 30000 on localhost.

item.title: Bandit: Level 15 => Level 16
item.description: The password for the next level can be retrieved by submitting the password of the current level to port 30001 on localhost using SSL encryption.

item.title: Bandit: Level 16 => Level 17
item.description: The credentials for the next level can be retrieved by submitting the password of the current level to a port on localhost in the range 31000 to 32000. First find out which of these ports have a server listening on them. Then find out which of those speak SSL and which don‚Äôt. There is only 1 server that will give the next credentials, the others will simply send back to you whatever you send to it.

item.title: Bandit: Level 17 => Level 18
item.description: There are 2 files in the homedirectory: `passwords.old and passwords.new`. The password for the next level is in `passwords.new` and is the only line that has been changed between `passwords.old and passwords.new`

item.title: Bandit: Level 18 => Level 19
item.description: The password for the next level is stored in a file `readme` in the homedirectory. Unfortunately, someone has modified `.bashrc` to log you out when you log in with SSH.

item.title: Bandit: Level 19 => Level 20
item.description: To gain access to the next level, you should use the `setuid` binary in the homedirectory. Execute it without arguments to find out how to use it. The password for this level can be found in the usual place `(/etc/bandit_pass)`, after you have used the setuid binary.

item.title: Bandit: Level 20 => Level 21
item.description: There is a setuid `binary` in the homedirectory that does the following: it makes a connection to localhost on the port you specify as a commandline argument. It then reads a line of text from the connection and compares it to the password in the previous level `bandit20`. If the password is correct, it will transmit the password for the next level `bandit21`.

item.title: Bandit: Level 21 => Level 22
item.description: A program is running automatically at regular intervals from `cron`, the time-based job scheduler. Look in `/etc/cron.d/` for the configuration and see what command is being executed.

item.title: Bandit: Level 22 => Level 23
item.description: A program is running automatically at regular intervals from cron, the time-based job scheduler. Look in /etc/cron.d/ for the configuration and see what command is being executed.

item.title: Bandit: Level 23 => Level 24
item.description: A program is running automatically at regular intervals from cron, the time-based job scheduler. Look in /etc/cron.d/ for the configuration and see what command is being executed.

item.title: Bandit: Level 24 => Level 25
item.description: A daemon is listening on port 30002 and will give you the password for bandit25 if given the password for bandit24 and a secret numeric 4-digit pin code. There is no way to retrieve the pin code except by going through all the 10000 combinations, called brute-forcing.

item.title: Bandit: Level 25 => Level 26
item.description: Logging in to bandit26 from bandit25 should be fairly easy‚Ä¶ The shell for user bandit26 is not /bin/bash, but something else. Find out what it is, how it works and how to break out of it.

item.title: Bandit: Level 26 => Level 27
item.description: Good job getting a shell! Now hurry and grab the password for `bandit27`!

item.title: Bandit: Level 27 => Level 28
item.description: There is a git repository at `ssh://bandit27-git@localhost/home/bandit27-git/repo` via the port `2220`. The password for the user `bandit27-git` is the same as for the user `bandit27`. Clone the repository and find the password for the next level.

item.title: Bandit: Level 28 => Level 29
item.description: There is a git repository at `ssh://bandit28-git@localhost/home/bandit28-git/repo` via the port `2220`. The password for the user `bandit28-git` is the same as for the user `bandit28`.

item.title: Bandit: Level 29 => Level 30
item.description: There is a git repository at `ssh://bandit29-git@localhost/home/bandit29-git/repo` via the port `2220`. The password for the user `bandit29-git` is the same as for the user `bandit29`.

item.title: Bandit: Level 30 => Level 31
item.description: There is a git repository at `ssh://bandit30-git@localhost/home/bandit30-git/repo` via the port `2220`. The password for the user `bandit30-git` is the same as for the user `bandit30`.

item.title: Bandit: Level 31 => Level 32
item.description: There is a git repository at ssh://bandit31-git@localhost/home/bandit31-git/repo via the port 2220. The password for the user bandit31-git is the same as for the user bandit31.

item.title: Bandit: Level 32 => Level 33
item.description: After all this git stuff, it‚Äôs time for another escape. Good luck!

item.title: üìë Bandit: Level 33 => Level 34
item.description: At this moment, level 34 does not exist.
